newsitem.title: FRANCE: Single-engine copter fails trans-Atlantic flight.
newsitem.headline: Single-engine copter fails trans-Atlantic flight.

text.p: A leak in a fuel tank prevented two French pilots on Saturday from carrying out the first non-stop trans-Atlantic flight by a single-engine helicopter.
"There has been a breakdown -- a leak in a reserve fuel tank," a spokeswoman for the attempt said.
"The helicopter has put down on an ocean barge. The leak would require welding and cannot be repaired, so the barge will carry them back to Gander in Canada," the spokeswoman said.
The helicopter had flown some 2,800 km (1,740 miles), a little more than halfway across the Atlantic, when it was forced to call off the flight, she added.

The Eurocopter ASTAR 350 B3 helicopter piloted by Philippe Boutry, 45, and Gerard David, 55, had lifted off from a small airfield at Teterboro, near New York, at about 2.15 p.m. EDT (1815 GMT) on Friday.
It had been expected at Le Bourget airport near Paris 27 hours later.

Equipped with special tanks and other gear enabling it to be refuelled in flight, it was scheduled to take on fuel five times -- at Fredericton, New Brunswick, and Gander, Newfoundland, and from tugs between Newfoundland and Europe.
The flight, sponsored by Eurocopter Group and Intertechnique Group, a French flight equipment company, had been designed to display in-flight refuelling equipment and techniques.
Eurocopter is owned by France's Ste Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale and Daimler-Benz Aerospace (DASA).
The Atlantic has been flown non-stop several times by multi-engine helicopters that refuelled en route.
